container-title: Leviathan: Contemporary Responses to the Political Theory of Thomas Hobbes
note: reprinted in Skinner, Visions of Politics III, ch. 9, surveys the contemporary reception of Leviathan and Hobbes’s other political works, casting doubt on the view that his political theory is based on moral obligations created by God. Further discussion can be found in Mark Goldie, “The Reception of Hobbes”, in J.H.Burns & Mark Goldie
title: Particularly valuable for source materials on the seventeenth-century reception of Leviathan is the selection reprinted in G.A.J
Also useful are the extracts reprinted as appendices to A.P.Martinich’s edition of Leviathan

Samuel Mintz’s The Hunting of Leviathan: seventeenth-century reactions to the materialism and moral philosophy of Thomas Hobbes (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press 1962) is quite old but still contains useful source material not readily available elsewhere. title: A useful discussion of the theoretical role played by the state of nature in justifying political authority generally (albeit with reference to Locke rather than to Hobbes) is Robert Nozick, Anarchy, State and Utopia

chs 1. and 2. For an interesting discussion of the theoretical uses of the state of nature, see W.R.Lund, “The Historical and ‘Political’ Origins of Civil Society: Hobbes on Presumption and Certainty”

For a discussion of how Hobbes derives the conclusion that life without government is a war of all against all from his initial account of the state of nature, see Gregory Kavka, “Hobbes’s War of All Against All”

author.particle: of Warrender’s position can be found in

note: The view that the source of the obligation to obey the law of nature lies in God is also advanced in F.C.Hood, The Divine Politics of Thomas Hobbes (Oxford: Clarendon Press
title: The place of God in Hobbes’s Philosophy”
Obligation and right in Hobbes”
and “Hobbes’s conception of morality”, Rivista Critica di storia della filosofia 17
Warrender’s reading of Leviathan was anticipated by A.E.Taylor earlier in the twentieth century. For Taylor’s version of the thesis, see “The Ethical Doctrine of Hobbes”
See also Taylor’s short monograph Thomas Hobbes
A more recent statement of the “theistic” interpretation of Hobbes is A.P.Martinich, The Two Gods of “Leviathan”: Thomas Hobbes on Religion and Politics
CRITICS OF THE THESIS For an important early criticism of Warrender’s position on obligation, see Thomas Nagel, “Hobbes’s Concept of Obligation”
See also Brian Barry “Warrender and His Critics”

container-title: and Skinner’s “Reply” in the same volume, pp692–95. A different defence of the view that Hobbes relies on a conception of moral obligation is in G.Schedler, “Hobbes on the Basis of Political Obligation”, Journal of the History of Philosophy
British Journal of the History of Philosophy
note: reprinted in Skinner, Visions of Politics III: Hobbes and Civil Science (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press 2002), ch. 9.
For a more recent view of the debate, see J.Curthoys, “Thomas Hobbes, the Taylor Thesis and Alasdair Macintyre”,
title: Further objections to the Taylor-Warrender thesis can also be found in Stuart M.Brown, The state of nature: law and right 67 “The Taylor Thesis: some objections”, and in John Plamenatz, “Mr Warrender’s Hobbes” and “The Taylor Thesis: introductory note”

Hobbes Studies. A contextualist critique of Warrender, which relies heavily on the fact that Hobbes’s political theory was widely received by his contemporaries as dispensing with any religious basis for political authority, is voiced by Quentin Skinner in “Hobbes’s Leviathan”’
which (savagely) reviews Hood’s, The Divine Politics of Thomas Hobbes; and Skinner’s “The context of Hobbes’s theory of political obligation”
For a response to Skinner, see B.T.Trainor, “Warrender and Skinner on Hobbes”

note: For critical discussion of Hampton, see Ishtiyaque Haji, “Hampton on State-of-Nature Cooperation”, Philosophy
title: Critical discussion of the game-theory interpretation Jodie Kraus, The Limits of Hobbesian Contractarianism (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press 1993) has a detailed discussion and comparison of the views of Gauthier, Hampton and Kavka. For further discussion, see Russell Hardin, “Hobbesian Political Order”

A more philosophical treatment of the concept of representation, both in general and in specific relation to Hobbes, appears in two articles by David Copp: “Collective Actions and Secondary Actions”

The most illuminating commentator on Hobbes’s theory of personhood, as it features in the theory of representation given in Leviathan, is David Runciman: see Pluralism and the Personality of the State

title: Debate”
Hobbes and leviathan 158 HOBBES AS AN ORTHODOX CHRISTIAN See the Further reading for Chapter Four above. For more on Hobbes’s own religious views
Hobbes’s Belief in God”

Hobbes’s Anglican Doctrine of Salvation”

note: and Hobbes and leviathan 174
title: Despite recent attempts at revision, Hobbes remains a central figure in the Realist tradition of thinking about international relations. A representative statement is Raino Malnes, The Hobbesian Theory of International Conflict
See also Robert Kagan, Paradise and Power: America and Europe in the New World Order
A similar view, but from a standpoint hostile to Realism, is expressed by Charles Beitz, Political Theory and International Relations
Further influential statements of the “Realist” interpretation of Hobbes can be found in Hedley Bull, “Hobbes and the International Anarchy”

note: See also Charles Covell, Hobbes, Realism, and the
title: Hobbes as an opponent of Realism An interpretation which tries to underline the ethical dimension of Hobbes’s thinking on international affairs, is Michael Williams, The Realist Tradition and the Limits of International Relations
and the same author’s “Hobbes and International Relations: a Reconsideration”

container-title: “Hobbes and the ‘Hobbesian Tradition’ in International Thought”, Millennium
note: A further departure from the Realist interpretation of Hobbes is offered by Noel
title: Tradition of International Law (Basingstoke: Palgrave 2004) for a further attempt to revise the accepted realist interpretation of Leviathan. Another statement of the same view can be found in A.Nuri Yurdusev, “Thomas Hobbes and International Relations: from realism to rationalism”
For earlier attempts to distance Hobbes from the Realist tradition, see John Vincent, “The Hobbesian Tradition in Twentieth-Century International Thought”
